Eliza has quitted the town,</br>And far from its pleasures remov'd;</br>From friends she entitled her own,</br>And scenes she could ever have lov'd.
To her friends that took leave of her last,</br>She breath'd out a tender adieu,</br>"Alas!  for the hours that are past,</br>Which I spent with Lorenzo and you."
Lorenzo, fond shepherd, was there,</br>And saw the lov'd nymph on her way;</br>"How cruel he cry'd, is my fair!</br>So sudden to hasten away."
But, why should the shepherd thus mourn?</br>Or give himself up to dispair;</br>For tho' she should never return,</br>Lorenzo may follow her there.
Adieu my Eliza — fair maid,</br>May health, and her sister — content,</br>With their rosy-cheek'd train be convey'd,</br>To where thy blest moments are spent.
May the Loves and the Graces unite,</br>And their influence over thee shine,</br>May the Virtues, become thy delight,</br>And their Beauties, Eliza, be thine.
May flatterers never attend,</br>Thy peace to invade or destroy,</br>But serenity smile to the end,</br>And thy Close, be without an alloy.</br>
